title: 109_hr4867
content: The "Puerto Rico Democracy Act of 2006" includes provisions for a federally sanctioned process for Puerto Rico's self-determination, initial plebiscite, subsequent procedures, applicable laws, and availability of funds. The Act is also known as the "Puerto Rico Democracy Act of 2006". The Congress acknowledges previous efforts by Presidents Bush and Clinton to address Puerto Rico's political status through referendums and task forces. President Clinton issued Executive Order 13183 to establish the President's Task Force on Puerto Rico's Status, which aimed to identify options for the territory's political future that align with US laws. President Bush later adopted and amended the order to outline the process for realizing these options. President George W. Bush adopted Executive Order 13183 and amended it to require the President's Task Force on Puerto Rico's Status to issue reports on progress made in determining Puerto Rico's ultimate status every two years. On December 22, 2005, the Task Force recommended options for Puerto Rico's future political status. The President's Task Force on Puerto Rico's Status, appointed by President George W. Bush, recommended a federally sanctioned plebiscite for the people of Puerto Rico to vote on remaining a US territory or pursuing a nonterritorial status. The President's Task Force on Puerto Rico's Status recommended a federally sanctioned plebiscite for the people of Puerto Rico to vote on their territorial status. If they choose a nonterritorial status, a subsequent plebiscite should be held to choose between two options. If the people of Puerto Rico elect a permanent nonterritorial status, Congress should provide a plebiscite for them to choose between two options. If they choose to remain a US territory, further plebiscites should be held. If Puerto Rico chooses a permanent nonterritorial status, Congress should offer a plebiscite with two options. If they opt to remain a US territory, periodic plebiscites should be held to update Congress on the people's preferences. "Establishing a federally sanctioned process for Puerto Rico's self-determination, including an initial plebiscite and subsequent procedures." The Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will conduct a plebiscite in Puerto Rico to choose between continuing the existing territorial status or pursuing a path towards a permanent nonterritorial status. The Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will conduct a plebiscite with two options: continuing the existing territorial status or pursuing a path towards a permanent nonterritorial status. Voters must mark their choice clearly as defined on the ballot. If a majority vote favors the existing territorial status in the first plebiscite, the procedure will be followed accordingly. If a majority vote favors the existing territorial status in the first plebiscite, the Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will conduct additional plebiscites every 8 years unless a majority votes for a permanent nonterritorial status. The Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will conduct additional plebiscites every 8 years unless a majority votes for a permanent nonterritorial status. If a majority favors permanent nonterritorial status, a plebiscite will be held with only two options to choose from. If a majority vote in a plebiscite favors permanent nonterritorial status, the Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will conduct a plebiscite with two options: statehood or becoming a sovereign nation. The Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will conduct a plebiscite with two options: statehood or becoming a sovereign nation. Voters can choose between Puerto Rico being admitted as a State of the Union or becoming a sovereign nation, either fully independent or in free association with the United States. The Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will conduct a plebiscite with two options: statehood or becoming a sovereign nation. If a majority vote favors permanent nonterritorial status, a plebiscite will be held during the 111th Congress, but no later than December 31, 2009. If a majority vote in a plebiscite favors permanent nonterritorial status, another plebiscite will be held within 2 years after the certification of the majority vote. SEC. 4. APPLICABLE LAWS AND OTHER REQUIREMENTS. The Federal laws applicable to the election of the Resident Commissioner of Puerto Rico also apply to any plebiscite held under this Act. Federal courts have exclusive jurisdiction over legal claims related to this Act. Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will issue necessary rules and regulations. The Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will issue rules and regulations for plebiscites under this Act. Federal courts have exclusive jurisdiction over legal claims related to the implementation of this Act. Eligible voters include those under Puerto Rico's electoral laws and US citizens born in Puerto Rico. Eligibility to vote in plebiscites under this Act includes all eligible voters under Puerto Rico's electoral laws and US citizens born in Puerto Rico who meet requirements set by the Puerto Rico State Elections Commission. The Puerto Rico State Elections Commission certifies the results of plebiscites to the President and Congress. Eligible voters can request an absentee ballot for plebiscites. The Puerto Rico State Elections Commission certifies plebiscite results to the President and Congress. The President's Task Force on Puerto Rico's Status must submit a report to Congress within 6 months after the plebiscite. After the plebiscite, the President's Task Force on Puerto Rico's Status will submit a report to Congress within 6 months, detailing measures to implement the chosen nonterritorial status option. SEC. 5. AVAILABILITY OF FUNDS FOR THE SELF-DETERMINATION PROCESS. During the period from October 1, 2006, until all plebiscites required by this Act are completed, the Secretary of the Treasury can allocate up to $5,000,000 from funds provided to Puerto Rico for election expenses. This includes voter education materials approved by the President's Task Force on Puerto Rico's Status. The Elections Commission of Puerto Rico will use funds allocated for plebiscites under this Act, including voter education materials approved by the President's Task Force on Puerto Rico's Status. The amounts will be determined as necessary for these purposes.
